title: 103_hr4512
content: The "Welfare to Work Act of 1994" is cited as the short title of the Act. The Congress expresses its sense regarding the Act. The Congress acknowledges the challenges faced by welfare recipients in finding permanent employment and emphasizes the importance of exchanging AFDC payments for work to break the cycle of welfare dependency. It is recognized that government workfare programs are not a substitute for gaining experience in the private sector, which can lead to long-term employment opportunities. A one-year tax credit is proposed to incentivize businesses to hire AFDC recipients and support their pathway to gainful employment. To support businesses in hiring AFDC recipients and promoting their transition to employment, a one-year tax credit is suggested for wages paid to employees leading to the termination of AFDC eligibility. A one-year tax credit is proposed for businesses hiring AFDC recipients to support their transition to employment. This involves amending the Internal Revenue Code to include a refundable credit for wages paid to employees leading to the termination of AFDC eligibility. The proposal suggests a tax credit for businesses hiring AFDC recipients, allowing a credit against the tax for the taxable year based on qualified first-year wages. Qualified first-year wages are defined as wages for services rendered during the 1-year period starting when the individual begins work for the employer. The term 'qualified wages' refers to wages paid to qualified former AFDC recipients by the employer during the taxable year. A qualified former AFDC recipient is an individual certified by the designated local agency as a member of a family receiving benefits under a State plan approved under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act, whose wages from the employer make the family ineligible for such benefits. The text discusses the eligibility criteria for qualified former AFDC recipients to receive certain benefits. It also mentions the prohibition on replacing existing workers to obtain credit. Additionally, technical amendments to the code are outlined. The text discusses technical amendments to the United States Code related to section 1324(b) of title 31 and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The text discusses technical amendments related to employment of AFDC recipients and overpayments of tax, with the amendments applying to individuals starting work after the enactment of the Act.
